pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Verañjā at the foot of Naḷeru’s Nimba tree with a large Sangha of five hundred monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.2: A brahmin in Verañjā was told:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.3: “Sir, the ascetic Gotama, the Sakyan, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan, is staying at Verañjā at the foot of Naleru’s Nimba tree with a large sangha of five hundred monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.4: That good Gotama has a fine reputation:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.5: ‘He is a Buddha, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme leader of trainable people, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, a Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.6: With his own insight he has seen this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and humans, and he makes it known to others.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.7: He has a Teaching that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end. It has a true goal and is well articulated. He sets out a perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.8: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.1: That brahmin then went to the Buddha, exchanged pleasantries with him, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.3: that you don’t bow down to old brahmins, stand up for them, or offer them a seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.4: I’ve now seen that this is indeed the case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.6: “Brahmin, in the world with its gods, lords of death, and supreme beings, in this society with its monastics and brahmins, its gods and humans, I don’t see anyone I should bow down to, rise up for, or offer a seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.7: If I did, their head would explode.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.2: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I lack taste.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.3: For I’ve abandoned the taste for forms, sounds, smells, flavors, and touches. I’ve cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, eradicated it, and made it incapable of reappearing in the future.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.4: But that’s not what you had in mind.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.6: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I have no enjoyment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.7: For I’ve abandoned the enjoyment of forms, sounds, smells, flavors, and touches. I’ve cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, eradicated it, and made it incapable of reappearing in the future.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.8: But that’s not what you had in mind.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.10: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I teach inaction.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.11: For I teach the non-doing of misconduct by body, speech, and mind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.12: I teach the non-doing of the various kinds of bad, unwholesome actions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.13: But that’s not what you had in mind.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.15: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I’m an annihilationist.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.16: For I teach the annihilation of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.17: I teach the annihilation of the various kinds of bad, unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.18: But that’s not what you had in mind.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.20: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I’m disgusting.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.21: For I am disgusted by misconduct by body, speech, and mind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.22: I am disgusted by the various kinds of bad, unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.23: But that’s not what you had in mind.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.25: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I’m an exterminator.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.26: For I teach the extermination of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.27: I teach the extermination of the various kinds of bad, unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.28: But that’s not what you had in mind.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.30: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I’m austere.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.31: For I say that bad, unwholesome qualities—misconduct by body, speech, and mind—are to be disciplined.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.32: One who has abandoned them, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, eradicated them, and made them incapable of reappearing in the future—such a one I call austere.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.33: Now I’ve abandoned the bad, unwholesome qualities that are to be disciplined. I’ve cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, eradicated them, and made them incapable of reappearing in the future.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.34: But that’s not what you had in mind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.36: “There’s a way you could rightly say that I’m an abortionist.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.37: For one who has abandoned any future conception in a womb, any rebirth in a future life, who has cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, eradicated it, and made it incapable of reappearing in the future—such a one I call an abortionist.

pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.1: Suppose, brahmin, there was a hen with eight, ten, or twelve eggs,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.2: which she had properly covered, warmed, and incubated.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.3: The first chick that hatches safely—after piercing through the eggshell with its claw or its beak—is it to be called the eldest or the youngest?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.5: for it’s the eldest among them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.6: “Just so, in this deluded society, enveloped like an egg, I alone in the world have cracked the shell of delusion and reached the supreme full awakening.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.7: I, brahmin, am the world’s eldest and best.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.1: I was firmly energetic and had clarity of mindfulness; my body was tranquil and my mind stilled and unified.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.2: Fully secluded from the five senses, secluded from unwholesome mental qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has movement of the mind, as well as the joy and bliss of seclusion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.3: Through the stilling of the movement of the mind, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has internal confidence and unification of mind, as well as the joy and bliss of stillness.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.4: Through the fading away of joy, I remained even-minded, mindful, and fully aware, experiencing bliss directly, and I entered and remained in the third absorption of which the noble ones declare:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.5: ‘You are even-minded, mindful, and abide in bliss.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.6: Through the abandoning of bliss and pain and the earlier ending of joy and aversion, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, which has neither pain nor bliss, but consists of purity of mindfulness and even-mindedness.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.1: Then, with my mind stilled, purified, cleansed, flawless, free from defilements, supple, wieldy, steady, and unshakable, I directed it to the knowledge that consists of recollecting past lives.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.2: I recollected many past lives, that is,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.3: one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births; many eons of world dissolution, many eons of world evolution, and many eons of both dissolution and evolution. And I knew:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.4: ‘There I had such name, such family, such appearance, such food, such experience of pleasure and pain, and such a lifespan.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.5: Passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.6: and there I had such name, such family, such appearance, such food, such experience of pleasure and pain, and such a lifespan.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.7: Passing away from there, I was reborn here.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.8: In this way I recollected many past lives with their characteristics and particulars.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.9: This was the first true insight, which I attained in the first part of the night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.10: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.11: as happens to one who is heedful, energetic, and diligent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.12: This, brahmin, was my first breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.1: Then, with my mind stilled, purified, cleansed, flawless, free from defilements, supple, wieldy, steady, and unshakable, I directed it to the knowledge of the passing away and arising of beings.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.2: With superhuman and purified clairvoyance, I saw beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and I understood how beings pass on according to their actions:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.3: ‘These beings who engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, who abused the noble ones, who had wrong views and acted accordingly,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.4: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a world of misery, hell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.5: But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not abuse the noble ones, who held right view and acted accordingly,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.6: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.7: In this way, with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, I saw beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and I understood how beings pass on according to their actions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.8: This was the second true insight, which I  attained in the middle part of the night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.9: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.10: as happens to one who is heedful, energetic, and diligent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.11: This, brahmin, was my second breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.1: Then, with my mind stilled, purified, cleansed, flawless, free from defilements, supple, wieldy, steady, and unshakable, I directed it to the knowledge of the ending of the corruptions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.2: I knew according to reality: ‘This is suffering;’ ‘This is the origin of suffering;’ ‘This is the end of suffering;’ ‘This is the path leading to the end of suffering.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.3: I knew according to reality: ‘These are the corruptions;’ ‘This is the origin of the corruptions;’ ‘This is the end of the corruptions;’ ‘This is the path leading to the end of the corruptions.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.4: When I knew and saw this, my mind was freed from the corruption of sensual desire, from the corruption of desire to exist, from the corruption of views, and from the corruption of delusion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.5: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.6: I understood that birth had come to an end, the spiritual life had been fulfilled, the job had been done, there was no further state of existence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.7: This was the third true insight, which I attained in the last part of the night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.8: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.9: as happens to one who is heedful, energetic, and diligent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.10: This, brahmin, was my third breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.1: That brahmin then said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.2: “Good Gotama is the eldest! Good Gotama is the best!
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.4: Just as one might set upright what’s overturned, or reveal what’s hidden, or show the way to one who’s lost, or bring a lamp into the dark so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.5: just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.6: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.7: Please accept me as a lay follower who’s gone for refuge for life.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.8: And please consent to spend the rainy-season residence at Verañjā together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.9: The Buddha consented by keeping silent, and the brahmin understood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.10: He then got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.1: At that time Verañjā was short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw. It was not easy to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.2: Just then some horse dealers from Uttarāpatha had entered the rainy-season residence at Verañjā with five hundred horses.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.3: In the horse pen they prepared portion upon portion of steamed grain for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.4: Then, after robing up in the morning, the monks took their bowls and robes and entered Verañjā for alms. Not getting anything, they went to the horse pen. They then brought back many portions of steamed grain to the monastery, where they pounded and ate them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.5: Venerable Ānanda crushed a portion on a stone, took it to the Buddha, and the Buddha ate it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.6: And the Buddha heard the sound of the mortar.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.7: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.8: They know the right time to ask and when not to ask.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.9: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, otherwise not,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.10: for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.11: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.12: And so the he said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, what’s this sound of a mortar?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.13: Ānanda told him what was happening.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.15: You’re all superior people who have conquered the problems of famine. Later generations will despise even meat and rice.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.1: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.2: “At present, Venerable Sir, Verañjā is short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.3: It’s not easy to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.4: But the undersurface of this great earth abounds with food, tasting just like pure honey.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.5: Would it be good, Sir, if I inverted the earth so that the monks may enjoy the nutrition in those sprouts?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.6: “But what will you do, Moggallāna, with the creatures that live there?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.7: “I’ll transform one hand to be like the great earth and make those creatures go there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.8: I’ll then invert the earth with the other hand.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.9: “Let it be, Moggallāna, don’t invert the earth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.10: Those creatures might lose their minds.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.11: “In that case, Sir, would it be good if the whole Sangha of monks could go to Uttarakuru for alms?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.12: “Let it be, Moggallāna, don’t pursue this.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.1: Soon afterwards, while reflecting in private, Venerable Sāriputta thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.2: “Which Buddhas had a long-lasting spiritual life, and which not?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.4: In the evening, after coming out of seclusion, Sāriputta went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.5: “Just now, Sir, while I was reflecting in private, I was wondering which Buddhas had a long-lasting spiritual life, and which not?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.7: “Sāriputta, the spiritual life established by the Buddhas Vipassī, Sikhī, and Vessabhū didn’t last long.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.8: But the spiritual life established by the Buddhas Kakusandha, Konāgamana, and Kassapa did.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.1: “And why did the spiritual life established by the former three Buddhas not last long?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.2: “They made no effort to give detailed teachings to their disciples.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.3: They gave few discourses in prose or in mixed prose and verse; few expositions, verses, heartfelt exclamations, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and analyses.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.4: Nor did they lay down training rules or recite a monastic code.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.5: After the disappearance of those Buddhas and the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples—of various names, families, and castes, who had gone forth from various households—allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.6: It’s like flowers on a wooden plank. If they’re not held together with a string, they’re scattered about, whirled about, and destroyed by the wind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.8: Because they’re not held together with a string.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.9: Just so, after the disappearance of those Buddhas and the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.10: Instead they were untiring at instructing their disciples by reading their minds.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.11: At one time, Sāriputta, the Buddha Vessabhū, the Perfected and the fully Awakened One, was staying in a certain frightening forest grove. He instructed a sangha of a thousand monks by reading their minds, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.13: pay attention like this, not like that;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.15: When they had been instructed by Buddha Vessabhū, their minds were freed from the corruptions through letting go.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.16: But if anyone with sensual desire entered that frightening forest grove, they usually had goosebumps all over.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.17: This is why the spiritual life established by those Buddhas did not last long.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.1: “Why then did the spiritual life established by the latter three Buddhas last long?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.2: “The Buddhas Kakusandha, Konāgamana, and Kassapa were untiring in giving detailed teachings to their disciples.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.3: They gave many discourses in prose and in mixed prose and verse; many expositions, verses, heartfelt exclamations, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and analyses.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.4: And they laid down training rules and recited a monastic code.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.5: After the disappearance of those Buddhas and the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples—of various names, families, and castes, who had gone forth from various households—made that spiritual life last for a long time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.6: It’s like flowers on a wooden plank. If they’re held together with a string, they’re not scattered about, whirled about, or destroyed by the wind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.8: Because they are held together with a string.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.9: Just so, after the disappearance of those Buddhas and the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples made that spiritual life last for a long time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.10: This is why the spiritual life established by those Buddhas lasted long.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.1: Sāriputta then got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.3: for laying down training rules and reciting a monastic code, so that this spiritual life may last for a long time.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.5: The Buddha knows the appropriate time for this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.6: The Teacher doesn’t lay down training rules or recite a monastic code until the causes of corruption appear in the Sangha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.7: And they don’t appear until the Sangha has attained long standing,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.11: an abundance of the best material support,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.14: When the causes of corruption appear for any of these reasons, then the Teacher lays down training rules for his disciples and recites a monastic code in order to counteract these causes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.15: Sāriputta, the Sangha of monks is free from cancer and danger, stainless, pure, and established in the essence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.16: Even the least developed of these five hundred monks is a stream-enterer. They will not be reborn in the lower world, but are fixed in destiny and bound for awakening.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.1: Then the Buddha said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, it’s the custom for Buddhas not to go wandering the country without taking leave of those who invited them to spend the rainy-season residence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.2: Let’s go to the brahmin of Verañjā and take leave.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.4: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe and, with Ānanda as his attendant, went to that brahmin’s house where he sat down on the prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.5: The brahmin approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.6: And the Buddha said, “Brahmin, we’ve completed the rains residence according to your invitation, and now we take leave of you.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.7: We wish to depart to wander the country.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.8: “It’s true, good Gotama, that you’ve completed the rains residence according to my invitation, but I haven’t given anything.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.10: It’s not because I didn’t want to, but because household life is so busy.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.11: Would you and the Sangha of monks please accept a meal from me tomorrow?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.12: The Buddha consented by keeping silent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.13: Then, after instructing, inspiring, and gladdening that brahmin with a teaching, the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
